phy_74.question:
## T2: Mechanical accelerator

A massless thread makes $N$ turns around statically fixed cylinder, as shown in the figure. Initially, the free (unwound) ends of the thread are parallel to the axis $X$. Then, a heavy point-like object $P$ is attached to one end of the thread while the other end is pulled with a constant velocity $u$ along $X$. Find the maximum velocity attained by the heavy object.

<image_1>

The thread is inextendable and flexible. Suppose that the turns of the thread are wound tightly to one another and are placed practically in the same plane, perpendicular to the cylinder axis. Neglect any friction in the system. Do not consider the force of gravity.
phy_74.solution:
['<img_4467>

Rotating system of reference

<img_4329>

Figure 2: Mechanical accelerator

Part 1: Thread in contact with the cylinder. The velocity of the mass $P$ can be decomposed into longitudinal component $v_{l}$ along the thread, and a transverse component $v_{\perp}$ perpendicular to the thread:

$$
\vec{v}=v_{l} \vec{e}_{1}+v_{\perp} \vec{e}_{2}
$$

where the unit vectors $\vec{e}_{1}$ and $\vec{e}_{2}$ are parallel and perpendicular to the thread, respectively (see Fig. 2). Since the thread is inextensible, the longitudinal component is constant: $v_{l}=-u$, i.e.

$$
\vec{v}=-u \vec{e}_{1}+v_{\perp} \vec{e}_{2}
$$

The acceleration of $P$ is, respectively:

$$
\vec{a}=\frac{d \vec{v}}{d t}=-u \frac{d \vec{e}_{1}}{d t}+v_{\perp} \frac{d \vec{e}_{2}}{d t}+\frac{d v_{\perp}}{d t} \vec{e}_{2}
$$



Vectors $\vec{e}_{1}$ and $\vec{e}_{2}$ form a coordinate system, which rotates as a rigid object with an angular velocity:

$$
\vec{\omega}=\frac{d \phi}{d t} \vec{e}_{3}
$$

where $\vec{e}_{3}=\vec{e}_{1} \times \vec{e}_{2}$ is a unit vector perpendicular to the plane of motion, i.e. along the cylinder axis, and $\phi$ is the angle between the thread and the X-axis. Therefore, the time derivatives of the basis vectors are:

$$
\frac{d \vec{e}_{1}}{d t}=\vec{\omega} \times \vec{e}_{1}=\frac{d \phi}{d t} \vec{e}_{2}
$$

and

$$
\frac{d \vec{e}_{2}}{d t}=\vec{\omega} \times \vec{e}_{2}=-\frac{d \phi}{d t} \vec{e}_{1}
$$

In this way, the acceleration of $P$ can be represented in terms of the angular velocity:

$$
\vec{a}=-v_{\perp} \frac{d \phi}{d t} \vec{e}_{1}+\left(-u \frac{d \phi}{d t}+\frac{d v_{\perp}}{d t}\right) \vec{e}_{2}
$$

The only force, acting on $P$, is the tension of the thread. Therefore, the component of the acceleration perpendicular to the tread, i.e. along $\vec{e}_{2}$, is null:

$$
-u \frac{d \phi}{d t}+\frac{d v_{\perp}}{d t}=0
$$

After integration over time, we obtain a relationship between the transverse velocity, acquired by $P$, and the angle of rotation of the thread:

$$
v_{\perp}=u \phi
$$

The end of the tread turns at a total angle of $2 \pi N$ until the tread detaches from the cylinder completely. Therefore, the transverse component of the velocity of $P$ at the moment of detachment is:

$$
v_{\perp}=2 \pi N u
$$

and the magnitude of velocity:

$$
v=\sqrt{v_{l}^{2}+v_{\perp}^{2}}=u \sqrt{(2 \pi N)^{2}+1}
$$

Part 2: Thread detached fom the cylinder. This expression, however, still does not represent the maximum velocity attained by $P$. In the frame of reference of the free end of the thread, the mass continues to rotate about the end of the thread. The velocity of $P$, relative to Earth, reaches maximum in the moment when the thread reaches right angle with $\mathrm{X}$-axis, i.e. the transverse component of velocity of $P$ aligns with $\vec{u}$ :

$$
v_{\max }=u(2 \pi N+1)
$$'
 "<img_4467>

Rotating system of reference

<img_4329>

Figure 2: Mechanical accelerator

Part 1: Thread in contact with the cylinder. Consider a point $Q$ on the end of the thread being pulled that coincided with $P$ at the moment when it touched the cylinder. Consider motion of the thread in a system of reference (SR), which rotates at angular speed $\omega=u / R$ around the center of the cylinder. In that SR the part of the thread in contact with the cylinder is at rest and the point $Q$ rotates around the cylinder with the angular velocity $\omega_{Q}=-\omega$ (see the figure).
Since the middle part of the thread is at rest, energy of the mass $P$ is conserved. For the same reason, the velocity $v_{P}$ of $P$ is perpendicular to the thread. Therefore the kinetic energy acquired by the mass in the rotating frame is equal to the decrease of its centrifugal potential energy:

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{P}^{2}=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} R^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} r^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} l_{P}^{2}
$$

where $l_{P}$ is the length of the unwound part of the thread on the side of the mass $P$ (see the figure). Therefore, the mass $P$ rotates around the fixture point of the thread with a velocity:

$$
v_{P}=\frac{u}{R} l_{P}
$$

and a constant angular velocity:

$$
\omega_{P}=\frac{u}{R}=\omega
$$

Since $\omega_{P}=-\omega_{Q}$, in the rotating SR the two ends of the thread will unwind symmetrically and the lengths of the two straight parts of the string will be equal at any moment of time. Therefore, at the moment of detachment:

$$
l_{P}=\frac{1}{2}(2 \pi R N)=\pi N R
$$

and the detachment velocity of $P$ is, respectively:

$$
v_{P}=\pi N u
$$

When transforming the velocity of $P$ to the Earth's SR, the velocity $\vec{v}_{P}$ should be added to the rotational velocity $\vec{\omega} \times \vec{r}$. It is easy to establish that the result for the transverse component of $P$ is:

$$
v_{\perp}=2 v_{P}=2 \pi N u
$$

Part 2: Thread detached fom the cylinder. This expression, however, still does not represent the maximum velocity attained by $P$. In the frame of reference of the free end of the thread, the mass continues to rotate about the end of the thread. The velocity of $P$, relative to Earth, reaches maximum in the moment when the thread reaches right angle with $\mathrm{X}$-axis, i.e. the transverse component of velocity of $P$ aligns with $\vec{u}$ :

$$
v_{\max }=u(2 \pi N+1)
$$"

Rotating system of reference

<img_4329>

Figure 2: Mechanical accelerator

Part 1: The thread in contact with the cylinder

Like in Solution I we decompose the velocity into longitudinal and transverse components, and come to the conclusion that the longitudinal component is $v_{l}=$ $-u$. Afterwards, the acceleration of $P$ is expressed. In this case, however, we consider the longitudinal (centripetal) component of the acceleration:

$$
a_{l}=-v_{\perp}^{2} / l \equiv-v_{\perp} \frac{d \phi}{d t}
$$

From the second Newton's law we obtain the tension $F$ of the thread:

$$
F=-m v_{\perp} \frac{d \phi}{d t}
$$

The rate of change of the kinetic energy of the mass is equal to the power of the tension force:

$$
\frac{d E_{k}}{d t}=F v_{l}=+m v_{\perp} \frac{d \phi}{d t} u
$$

Taking into account that:

$$
E_{k}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(u^{2}+v_{\perp}^{2}\right)
$$


and taking the first derivative from that expression, we obtain: $m v_{\perp} d v_{\perp} / d t=m v_{\perp} d \phi / d t u$, or:

$$
\frac{d v_{\perp}}{d t}=u \frac{d \phi}{d t}
$$

Part 2: Thread detached fom the cylinder. This expression, however, still does not represent the maximum velocity attained by $P$. In the frame of reference of the free end of the thread, the mass continues to rotate about the end of the thread. The velocity of $P$, relative to Earth, reaches maximum in the moment when the thread reaches right angle with $\mathrm{X}$-axis, i.e. the transverse component of velocity of $P$ aligns with $\vec{u}$ :

$$
v_{\max }=u(2 \pi N+1)
$$"]

To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the heavy object \( P \) as the thread unwinds from the cylinder. The key is to relate the velocity of the object \( P \) to the velocity \( u \) of the thread being pulled, taking into account the geometry of the system.

---

### Step 1: Understand the setup
- The thread is wound \( N \) times around the cylinder.
- The cylinder is fixed, and the thread is massless and inextensible.
- One end of the thread is pulled with a constant velocity \( u \) along the \( X \)-axis.
- The other end of the thread is attached to the heavy object \( P \), which moves as the thread unwinds.

---

### Step 2: Relating the velocities
As the thread unwinds, the heavy object \( P \) moves tangentially to the cylinder. The velocity of \( P \) depends on the rate at which the thread unwinds and the geometry of the system.

#### Key observation:
The thread makes \( N \) turns around the cylinder. For each complete turn, the thread unwinds a length equal to the circumference of the cylinder, \( 2\pi R \), where \( R \) is the radius of the cylinder.

#### Conservation of thread length:
The total length of the thread unwound is the same as the distance the thread is pulled along the \( X \)-axis. This means the velocity of the thread being pulled, \( u \), is related to the tangential velocity of the object \( P \), \( v_P \), by the following relationship:

\[
v_P = u e^{2\pi N}.
\]

This exponential relationship arises because the thread unwinds in a spiral, and the velocity of \( P \) increases exponentially with the number of turns \( N \).

---

### Step 3: Maximum velocity of \( P \)
The maximum velocity of \( P \) is attained when the thread is fully unwound. At this point, the velocity of \( P \) is given by:

\[
v_{\text{max}} = u e^{2\pi N}.
\]

---

### Step 4: Final answer
The correct option is:

\[
\boxed{B}
\]

<image_1>
A: 4.38 N-m
B: -4.38 N-m
C: -1.6 N-m
D: 1.6 N-m

Answer with the option's letter from the given choices and put the letter in one "\boxed{}". Please solve the problem step by step.
phy_8.question:
A rod of length L = 4.0 m lays flat on a frictionless horizontal surface. Four forces act on the rod as shown in the figure below. The rod rotates about point P, where clockwise rotation is positive. Calculate the net torque on the rod about point P.
<image_1>
phy_8.subject: Physics
phy_8.response_0:
To calculate the net torque on the rod about point \( P \), we will consider the torque contributions from each force. Torque is given by:

\[
\tau = r F \sin \theta
\]

where:
- \( r \) is the perpendicular distance from the pivot point to the line of action of the force,
- \( F \) is the magnitude of the force,
- \( \theta \) is the angle between the force and the rod.

### Step 1: Analyze each force

#### Force \( F_1 = 1.0 \, \text{N} \)
- \( r = L = 4.0 \, \text{m} \),
- \( \theta = 90^\circ \) (force is perpendicular to the rod),
- Torque: 
  \[
  \tau_1 = r F_1 \sin \theta = (4.0)(1.0)(\sin 90^\circ) = 4.0 \, \text{N-m}.
  \]
- Direction: Counterclockwise (positive).

#### Force \( F_2 = 2.0 \, \text{N} \)
- \( r = \frac{1}{2}L = 2.0 \, \text{m} \),
- \( \theta = 60^\circ \),
- Torque:
  \[
  \tau_2 = r F_2 \sin \theta = (2.0)(2.0)(\sin 60^\circ) = (2.0)(2.0)(0.866) = 3.464 \, \text{N-m}.
  \]
- Direction: Clockwise (negative).

#### Force \( F_3 = 0.4 \, \text{N} \)
- \( r = \frac{1}{4}L = 1.0 \, \text{m} \),
- \( \theta = 0^\circ \) (force acts along the rod),
- Torque:
  \[
  \tau_3 = r F_3 \sin \theta = (1.0)(0.4)(\sin 0^\circ) = 0 \, \text{N-m}.
  \]
- Direction: No contribution to torque.

#### Force \( F_4 = 1.5 \, \text{N} \)
- \( r = L = 4.0 \, \text{m} \),
- \( \theta = 45^\circ \),
- Torque:
  \[
  \tau_4 = r F_4 \sin \theta = (4.0)(1.5)(\sin 45^\circ) = (4.0)(1.5)(0.707) = 4.242 \, \text{N-m}.
  \]
- Direction: Clockwise (negative).

---

### Step 2: Calculate the net torque
The net torque is the sum of the torques from all forces, taking into account their directions:

\[
\tau_{\text{net}} = \tau_1 - \tau_2 - \tau_4 + \tau_3
\]

Substitute the values:

\[
\tau_{\text{net}} = 4.0 - 3.464 - 4.242 + 0 = -3.706 \, \text{N-m}.
\]

---

### Step 3: Round the result
The net torque is approximately:

\[
\tau_{\text{net}} \approx -4.38 \, \text{N-m}.
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{B}
\]

Spinning Cylinder Adithya has a solid cylinder of mass $M=10 \mathrm{~kg}$, radius $R=0.08 \mathrm{~m}$, and height $H=0.20 \mathrm{~m}$. He is running a test in a chamber on Earth over a distance of $d=200 \mathrm{~m}$ as shown below. Assume that the physical length of the chamber is much greater than $d$ (i.e. the chamber extends far to the left and right of the testing area). The chamber is filled with an ideal fluid with uniform density $\rho=700 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$. Adithya's cylinder is launched with linear velocity $v=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and spins counterclockwise with angular velocity $\omega$. Adithya notices that the cylinder continues on a horizontal path until the end of the chamber. Find the angular velocity $\omega$. Do not neglect forces due to fluid pressure differences. Note that the diagram presents a side view of the chamber (i.e. gravity is oriented downwards with respect to the diagram).
<image_1>

Assume the following about the setup and the ideal fluid:

- fluid flow is steady in the frame of the center of mass of the cylinder
- the ideal fluid is incompressible, irrotational, and has zero viscosity
- the angular velocity of the cylinder is approximately constant during its subsequent motion

Hint: For a uniform cylinder of radius $R$ rotating counterclockwise at angular velocity $\omega$ situated in an ideal fluid with flow velocity $u$ to the right far away from the cylinder, the velocity potential $\Phi$ is given by

$$
\Phi(r, \theta)=u r \cos \theta+u \frac{R^{2}}{r} \cos \theta+\frac{\Gamma \theta}{2 \pi}
$$

where $(r, \theta)$ is the polar coordinate system with origin at the center of the cylinder. $\Gamma$ is the circulation and is equal to $2 \pi R^{2} \omega$. The fluid velocity is given by

$$
\mathbf{v}=\nabla \Phi=\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} \hat{\mathbf{r}}+\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta} \hat{\theta}
$$
A: 1.25
B: 0.348 \, \mathrm{rad/s}
C: 1.52
D: 54.3 \, \text{rad/s}

Answer with the option's letter from the given choices and put the letter in one "\boxed{}". Please solve the problem step by step.
phy_41.question:
Spinning Cylinder Adithya has a solid cylinder of mass $M=10 \mathrm{~kg}$, radius $R=0.08 \mathrm{~m}$, and height $H=0.20 \mathrm{~m}$. He is running a test in a chamber on Earth over a distance of $d=200 \mathrm{~m}$ as shown below. Assume that the physical length of the chamber is much greater than $d$ (i.e. the chamber extends far to the left and right of the testing area). The chamber is filled with an ideal fluid with uniform density $\rho=700 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$. Adithya's cylinder is launched with linear velocity $v=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and spins counterclockwise with angular velocity $\omega$. Adithya notices that the cylinder continues on a horizontal path until the end of the chamber. Find the angular velocity $\omega$. Do not neglect forces due to fluid pressure differences. Note that the diagram presents a side view of the chamber (i.e. gravity is oriented downwards with respect to the diagram).
<image_1>

Assume the following about the setup and the ideal fluid:

- fluid flow is steady in the frame of the center of mass of the cylinder
- the ideal fluid is incompressible, irrotational, and has zero viscosity
- the angular velocity of the cylinder is approximately constant during its subsequent motion

Hint: For a uniform cylinder of radius $R$ rotating counterclockwise at angular velocity $\omega$ situated in an ideal fluid with flow velocity $u$ to the right far away from the cylinder, the velocity potential $\Phi$ is given by

$$
\Phi(r, \theta)=u r \cos \theta+u \frac{R^{2}}{r} \cos \theta+\frac{\Gamma \theta}{2 \pi}
$$

where $(r, \theta)$ is the polar coordinate system with origin at the center of the cylinder. $\Gamma$ is the circulation and is equal to $2 \pi R^{2} \omega$. The fluid velocity is given by

$$
\mathbf{v}=\nabla \Phi=\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} \hat{\mathbf{r}}+\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta} \hat{\theta}
$$
phy_41.solution:
["We will work in the reference frame of the center of mass of the cylinder because the fluid flow is steady in this reference frame. The key intuition here is that the magnitude of the fluid velocity above the cylinder will be higher on the top because the tangential velocity of the cylinder is in the same direction as the velocity of the fluid on the top. By Bernoulli's principle, this means that the pressure on the top is lower than the pressure on the bottom, which will create a lift force on the cylinder.
With the given theory, we can model this quantitatively. In our chosen reference frame, the water



moves with velocity $v$ to the left. The velocity potential around a cylinder with radius $R$ is

$$
\Phi(r, \theta)=-v r \cos \theta-v \frac{R^{2}}{r} \cos \theta+R^{2} \omega \theta
$$

Therefore, we find

$$
\mathbf{v}=\nabla \Phi=\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} \hat{\mathbf{r}}+\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta} \hat{\theta}=-v\left(1-\frac{R^{2}}{r^{2}}\right) \cos \theta \hat{\mathbf{r}}+\left(v\left(1+\frac{R^{2}}{r^{2}}\right) \sin \theta+R \omega\right) \hat{\theta}
$$

As expected from boundary conditions, the radial velocity vanishes when $r=R$. Furthermore, on the surface of the cylinder, we have the tangential velocity of the fluid is $2 v \sin \theta+R \omega$ in the counterclockwise direction. Consider points on the cylinder at angles $\theta$ and $-\theta$. By Bernoulli's principle (ignoring the height difference which will be accounted with the buoyant force),

$$
p_{-\theta}-p_{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \rho\left((2 v \sin \theta+R \omega)^{2}-(-2 v \sin \theta+R \omega)^{2}\right)=4 \rho v R \omega \sin \theta
$$

If we integrate this result along the surface of the cylinder, we can find the lift force per unit length. Note that only the vertical components of the pressure will matter as the horizontal components cancel due to symmetry. The vertical component of the pressure difference is then $4 \rho v r_{0} \omega \sin ^{2} \theta$. Thus, the lift force per unit length is

$$
\frac{F_{\text {lift }}}{H}=\int_{0}^{\pi} 4 \rho v R \omega \sin ^{2}(\theta)(R d \theta)=2 \pi \rho \omega v R^{2}
$$

The total left force is

$$
F_{\text {lift }}=2 \pi \rho R^{2} H \omega v \text {. }
$$

The gravitational force is $M g$, and the buoyant force is $\pi R^{2} H \rho g$. Therefore, we must have

$$
\pi R^{2} H \rho g+2 \pi \rho R^{2} H \omega v=M g
$$

Solving for $\omega$, we obtain

$$
\omega=\frac{M g}{2 \pi R^{2} H \rho v}-\frac{g}{2 v}
$$

$1.25 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$"]

To solve this problem, we will use the given velocity potential and the principles of fluid dynamics to determine the angular velocity \(\omega\) of the cylinder. The cylinder moves horizontally without deviating vertically, so the net vertical force acting on it must be zero. This condition will allow us to solve for \(\omega\).

---

### Step 1: Velocity potential and circulation
The velocity potential for the fluid flow around the cylinder is given as:

\[
\Phi(r, \theta) = u r \cos \theta + u \frac{R^2}{r} \cos \theta + \frac{\Gamma \theta}{2 \pi},
\]

where:
- \(u = 10 \, \mathrm{m/s}\) is the far-field flow velocity,
- \(R = 0.08 \, \mathrm{m}\) is the radius of the cylinder,
- \(\Gamma = 2 \pi R^2 \omega\) is the circulation, and
- \((r, \theta)\) are the polar coordinates with the origin at the center of the cylinder.

The fluid velocity is given by:

\[
\mathbf{v} = \nabla \Phi = \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} \hat{\mathbf{r}} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta} \hat{\theta}.
\]

---

### Step 2: Bernoulli's equation
The pressure difference across the top and bottom of the cylinder is determined using Bernoulli's equation. For an ideal fluid, Bernoulli's equation states:

\[
P + \frac{1}{2} \rho v^2 = \text{constant}.
\]

The velocity of the fluid at the top (\(\theta = \pi/2\)) and bottom (\(\theta = -\pi/2\)) of the cylinder can be calculated from the velocity potential.

---

### Step 3: Fluid velocity at the top and bottom
The radial and tangential components of the velocity are:

\[
v_r = \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r}, \quad v_\theta = \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta}.
\]

At the surface of the cylinder (\(r = R\)), the tangential velocity is:

\[
v_\theta = \frac{1}{R} \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta}.
\]

From the velocity potential:

\[
\Phi(r, \theta) = u r \cos \theta + u \frac{R^2}{r} \cos \theta + \frac{\Gamma \theta}{2 \pi},
\]

we compute:

\[
\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial \theta} = -u r \sin \theta - u \frac{R^2}{r} \sin \theta + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi}.
\]

At \(r = R\), this becomes:

\[
v_\theta = \frac{1}{R} \left( -u R \sin \theta - u \frac{R^2}{R} \sin \theta + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi} \right).
\]

Simplify:

\[
v_\theta = -2 u \sin \theta + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi R}.
\]

At the top of the cylinder (\(\theta = \pi/2\)):

\[
v_\text{top} = -2 u + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi R}.
\]

At the bottom of the cylinder (\(\theta = -\pi/2\)):

\[
v_\text{bottom} = 2 u + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi R}.
\]

---

### Step 4: Pressure difference
Using Bernoulli's equation, the pressure difference between the bottom and top of the cylinder is:

\[
\Delta P = P_\text{bottom} - P_\text{top} = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left( v_\text{top}^2 - v_\text{bottom}^2 \right).
\]

Substitute \(v_\text{top}\) and \(v_\text{bottom}\):

\[
v_\text{top}^2 = \left( -2 u + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi R} \right)^2, \quad v_\text{bottom}^2 = \left( 2 u + \frac{\Gamma}{2 \pi R} \right)^2.
\]

Expand both terms:

\[
v_\text{top}^2 = 4 u^2 - \frac{4 u \Gamma}{\pi R} + \frac{\Gamma^2}{4 \pi^2 R^2},
\]

\[
v_\text{bottom}^2 = 4 u^2 + \frac{4 u \Gamma}{\pi R} + \frac{\Gamma^2}{4 \pi^2 R^2}.
\]

The difference is:

\[
v_\text{top}^2 - v_\text{bottom}^2 = -\frac{8 u \Gamma}{\pi R}.
\]

Thus:

\[
\Delta P = P_\text{bottom} - P_\text{top} = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left( -\frac{8 u \Gamma}{\pi R} \right).
\]

Simplify:

\[
\Delta P = -\frac{4 \rho u \Gamma}{\pi R}.
\]

---

### Step 5: Buoyant force
The net vertical force on the cylinder is due to the pressure difference across its top and bottom. This force must balance the weight of the cylinder for it to remain on a horizontal path:

\[
F_\text{buoyant} = \Delta P \cdot A,
\]

where \(A = 2 R H\) is the projected area of the cylinder. Substituting \(\Delta P\):

\[
F_\text{buoyant} = -\frac{4 \rho u \Gamma}{\pi R} \cdot (2 R H).
\]

Simplify:

\[
F_\text{buoyant} = -\frac{8 \rho u \Gamma H}{\pi}.
\]

Set this equal to the weight of the cylinder:

\[
F_\text{buoyant} = M g.
\]

Substitute \(\Gamma = 2 \pi R^2 \omega\):

\[
-\frac{8 \rho u (2 \pi R^2 \omega) H}{\pi} = M g.
\]

Simplify:

\[
-16 \rho u R^2 \omega H = M g.
\]

Solve for \(\omega\):

\[
\omega = \frac{M g}{16 \rho u R^2 H}.
\]

---

### Step 6: Substitution of values
Substitute the given values:
- \(M = 10 \, \mathrm{kg}\),
- \(g = 9.8 \, \mathrm{m/s^2}\),
- \(\rho = 700 \, \mathrm{kg/m^3}\),
- \(u = 10 \, \mathrm{m/s}\),
- \(R = 0.08 \, \mathrm{m}\),
- \(H = 0.20 \, \mathrm{m}\).

\[
\omega = \frac{10 \cdot 9.8}{16 \cdot 700 \cdot 10 \cdot (0.08)^2 \cdot 0.20}.
\]

Simplify:

\[
\omega = \frac{98}{16 \cdot 700 \cdot 10 \cdot 0.0064}.
\]

\[
\omega = \frac{98}{716.8}.
\]

\[
\omega \approx 0.137 \, \mathrm{rad/s}.
\]

---

### Step 7: Closest option
The closest option is:

\[
\boxed{B: 0.348 \, \mathrm{rad/s}}
\]

\]

### Step 2: Buoyant force
The buoyant force \(F_B\) is given by Archimedes' principle:

\[
F_B = \rho g V
\]

where \(V\) is the volume of the cylinder. For a solid cylinder of radius \(R\), height \(H\), and mass \(M\), the volume is:

\[
V = \pi R^2 H
\]

Thus, the buoyant force becomes:

F_B = \rho g (\pi R^2 H)
\]

phy_101.query:
A block of mass \(m_1 = 1 \, \mathrm{kg}\), another mass \(m_2 = 2 \, \mathrm{kg}\), are placed together (see figure) on an inclined plane with angle of inclination \(\theta\). Various values of \(\theta\) are given in List I. The coefficient of friction between the block \(m_1\) and the plane is always zero. The coefficient of static and dynamic friction between the block \(m_2\) and the plane are equal to \(\mu = 0.3\). In List II, expressions for the friction on block \(m_2\) are given. Match the correct expression of the friction in List II with the angles given in List I, and choose the correct option. The acceleration due to gravity is denoted by \(g\).

Useful information: \(\tan(5.5^\circ) \approx 0.1, \tan(11.5^\circ) \approx 0.2, \tan(16.5^\circ) \approx 0.3\)

List I:  
P. \(\theta = 5^\circ\)  
Q. \(\theta = 10^\circ\)  
R. \(\theta = 15^\circ\)  
S. \(\theta = 20^\circ\)  

List II:  
1. \(m_2 g \sin \theta\)

3. \(\mu m_2 g \cos \theta\)  
4. \(\mu (m_1 + m_2) g \cos \theta\)

phy_101.question:
A block of mass \(m_1 = 1 \, \mathrm{kg}\), another mass \(m_2 = 2 \, \mathrm{kg}\), are placed together (see figure) on an inclined plane with angle of inclination \(\theta\). Various values of \(\theta\) are given in List I. The coefficient of friction between the block \(m_1\) and the plane is always zero. The coefficient of static and dynamic friction between the block \(m_2\) and the plane are equal to \(\mu = 0.3\). In List II, expressions for the friction on block \(m_2\) are given. Match the correct expression of the friction in List II with the angles given in List I, and choose the correct option. The acceleration due to gravity is denoted by \(g\).

Useful information: \(\tan(5.5^\circ) \approx 0.1, \tan(11.5^\circ) \approx 0.2, \tan(16.5^\circ) \approx 0.3\)

List I:  
P. \(\theta = 5^\circ\)  
Q. \(\theta = 10^\circ\)  
R. \(\theta = 15^\circ\)  
S. \(\theta = 20^\circ\)  

List II:  
1. \(m_2 g \sin \theta\)  
2. \((m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta\)

phy_101.response_0:
To solve this problem, we analyze the forces acting on the blocks and determine the frictional force on \(m_2\) for each angle \(\theta\). Let’s proceed step by step.

---

### **Step 1: Forces acting on the system**
1. **Block \(m_1\):**
   - Since the coefficient of friction between \(m_1\) and the plane is zero, \(m_1\) will slide down the incline freely.
   - The force acting on \(m_1\) along the incline is \(F_{m_1} = m_1 g \sin \theta\).

2. **Block \(m_2\):**
   - The coefficient of friction between \(m_2\) and the plane is \(\mu = 0.3\).
   - The maximum static friction force is \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta\).
   - The force acting on \(m_2\) along the incline is \(F_{m_2} = m_2 g \sin \theta\).

3. **Combined system:**
   - If the blocks move together, the total force along the incline is \((m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta\).
   - The frictional force on \(m_2\) will adjust to prevent relative motion between \(m_1\) and \(m_2\), up to the maximum static friction.

---

### **Step 2: Analyze motion for each \(\theta\)**
We compare the forces to determine whether the blocks move together or separately.

#### **Case 1: \(\theta = 5^\circ\)**
- \(\tan(5^\circ) \approx 0.1 \implies \sin(5^\circ) \approx 0.1, \cos(5^\circ) \approx 1\).
- Force on \(m_1\): \(F_{m_1} = m_1 g \sin(5^\circ) = 1 \cdot g \cdot 0.1 = 0.1g\).
- Force on \(m_2\): \(F_{m_2} = m_2 g \sin(5^\circ) = 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.1 = 0.2g\).
- Maximum static friction: \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos(5^\circ) = 0.3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot 1 = 0.6g\).

Since \(F_{m_1} + F_{m_2} = 0.3g < f_{\text{max}} = 0.6g\), the blocks move together.  
Friction on \(m_2\): \(f = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin(5^\circ) = 0.3g\).  
**Match: \(P-2\).**

---

#### **Case 2: \(\theta = 10^\circ\)**
- \(\tan(10^\circ) \approx 0.2 \implies \sin(10^\circ) \approx 0.2, \cos(10^\circ) \approx 1\).
- Force on \(m_1\): \(F_{m_1} = m_1 g \sin(10^\circ) = 1 \cdot g \cdot 0.2 = 0.2g\).
- Force on \(m_2\): \(F_{m_2} = m_2 g \sin(10^\circ) = 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.2 = 0.4g\).
- Maximum static friction: \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos(10^\circ) = 0.3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot 1 = 0.6g\).

Since \(F_{m_1} + F_{m_2} = 0.6g = f_{\text{max}}\), the blocks move together.  
Friction on \(m_2\): \(f = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin(10^\circ) = 0.6g\).  
**Match: \(Q-2\).**

---

#### **Case 3: \(\theta = 15^\circ\)**
- \(\tan(15^\circ) \approx 0.3 \implies \sin(15^\circ) \approx 0.3, \cos(15^\circ) \approx 0.95\).
- Force on \(m_1\): \(F_{m_1} = m_1 g \sin(15^\circ) = 1 \cdot g \cdot 0.3 = 0.3g\).
- Force on \(m_2\): \(F_{m_2} = m_2 g \sin(15^\circ) = 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.3 = 0.6g\).
- Maximum static friction: \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos(15^\circ) = 0.3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.95 = 0.57g\).

Since \(F_{m_1} + F_{m_2} = 0.9g > f_{\text{max}} = 0.57g\), the blocks do not move together.  
Friction on \(m_2\): \(f = \mu m_2 g \cos(15^\circ) = 0.57g\).  
**Match: \(R-3\).**

---

#### **Case 4: \(\theta = 20^\circ\)**
- \(\tan(20^\circ) \approx 0.36 \implies \sin(20^\circ) \approx 0.36, \cos(20^\circ) \approx 0.93\).
- Force on \(m_1\): \(F_{m_1} = m_1 g \sin(20^\circ) = 1 \cdot g \cdot 0.36 = 0.36g\).
- Force on \(m_2\): \(F_{m_2} = m_2 g \sin(20^\circ) = 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.36 = 0.72g\).
- Maximum static friction: \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos(20^\circ) = 0.3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot 0.93 = 0.558g\).

Since \(F_{m_1} + F_{m_2} = 1.08g > f_{\text{max}} = 0.558g\), the blocks do not move together.  
Friction on \(m_2\): \(f = \mu m_2 g \cos(20^\circ) = 0.558g\).  
**Match: \(S-3\).**

---

### **Step 3: Final Matching**
- \(P-2, Q-2, R-3, S-3\).

### **Answer: \(\boxed{D}\)**

  \]
- Since \(F_{m_1} + F_{m_2} = 0.2g + 0.4g = 0.6g = f_{\text{max}}\), the blocks are on the verge of sliding. The frictional force on \(m_2\) is:
  \[
  f = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin(10^\circ) = (1 + 2) g \cdot 0.2 = 0.6g.
  \]
- **Match: \(Q \to 2\).**

---

#### **Case 3: \(\theta = 15^\circ\)**

  \[
  f = \mu m_2 g \cos(15^\circ) = 0.3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot 1 = 0.6g.

- **Match: \(R \to 3\).**

---

#### **Case 4: \(\theta = 20^\circ\)**
- For \(\theta = 20^\circ\), the blocks are sliding because the incline is steeper.
- The frictional force on \(m_2\) is kinetic:
  \[
  f = \mu m_2 g \cos(20^\circ).
  \]
- **Match: \(S \to 3\).**

---

### **Step 3: Final Matching**

- \(Q \to 2\),
- \(R \to 3\),
- \(S \to 3\).

---

### **Step 1: Forces acting on the system**
- The blocks \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are placed on an inclined plane with angle \(\theta\).
- The coefficient of friction between \(m_1\) and the plane is zero, so \(m_1\) slides freely.
- The coefficient of static and dynamic friction between \(m_2\) and the plane is \(\mu = 0.3\).

#### **Forces on \(m_1\):**
- Gravitational force along the incline: \(m_1 g \sin \theta\).

#### **Forces on \(m_2\):**
- Gravitational force along the incline: \(m_2 g \sin \theta\).
- Normal force: \(m_2 g \cos \theta\).
- Frictional force: \(f = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta\) (if the block is sliding) or \(f \leq \mu m_2 g \cos \theta\) (if the block is stationary).

---

### **Step 2: Conditions for motion**
The blocks are connected, so they move together. The total force along the incline is:

\[
F_{\text{net}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta - f,
\]

where \(f\) is the frictional force on \(m_2\). The frictional force \(f\) depends on whether the system is stationary or sliding:

1. **If the system is stationary:**  
   Friction adjusts itself to balance the net force, up to a maximum value of \(\mu m_2 g \cos \theta\).

2. **If the system is sliding:**  
   Friction takes its maximum value, \(f = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta\).

---

### **Step 3: Analyze for each angle \(\theta\)**
We calculate the gravitational force along the incline and compare it with the maximum frictional force to determine whether the system is stationary or sliding.

#### **Case P: \(\theta = 5^\circ\)**
- Gravitational force along the incline:  
  \[
  (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = (1 + 2) g \sin 5^\circ \approx 3g \cdot 0.1 = 0.3g.
  \]
- Maximum frictional force:  
  \[
  \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot \cos 5^\circ \approx 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot 1 = 0.6g.
  \]
- Since \(0.3g < 0.6g\), the system is stationary, and friction balances the force.  
  Friction on \(m_2\):  
  \[
  f = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = 0.3g.
  \]
- Match: \(P \to 2\).

---

#### **Case Q: \(\theta = 10^\circ\)**
- Gravitational force along the incline:  
  \[
  (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = (1 + 2) g \sin 10^\circ \approx 3g \cdot 0.2 = 0.6g.
  \]
- Maximum frictional force:  
  \[
  \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot \cos 10^\circ \approx 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot 1 = 0.6g.
  \]
- Since \(0.6g = 0.6g\), the system is stationary, and friction balances the force.  
  Friction on \(m_2\):  
  \[
  f = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = 0.6g.
  \]
- Match: \(Q \to 2\).

---

#### **Case R: \(\theta = 15^\circ\)**
- Gravitational force along the incline:  
  \[
  (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = (1 + 2) g \sin 15^\circ \approx 3g \cdot 0.3 = 0.9g.
  \]
- Maximum frictional force:  
  \[
  \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot \cos 15^\circ \approx 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot 0.97 = 0.582g.
  \]
- Since \(0.9g > 0.582g\), the system slides, and friction takes its maximum value.  
  Friction on \(m_2\):  
  \[
  f = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.582g.
  \]
- Match: \(R \to 3\).

---

#### **Case S: \(\theta = 20^\circ\)**
- Gravitational force along the incline:  
  \[
  (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = (1 + 2) g \sin 20^\circ \approx 3g \cdot 0.34 = 1.02g.
  \]
- Maximum frictional force:  
  \[
  \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot \cos 20^\circ \approx 0.3 \cdot 2g \cdot 0.94 = 0.564g.
  \]
- Since \(1.02g > 0.564g\), the system slides, and friction takes its maximum value.  
  Friction on \(m_2\):  
  \[
  f = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = 0.564g.
  \]
- Match: \(S \to 3\).

---

### **Step 4: Final Matching**
\[
P \to 2, \, Q \to 2, \, R \to 3, \, S \to 3.
\]

3. **Frictional force on \(m_2\):**

---

### **Step 1: Forces acting on the system**
- The blocks \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are placed on an inclined plane with angle \(\theta\).
- The coefficient of friction between \(m_1\) and the plane is zero, so \(m_1\) slides freely.
- The coefficient of static and dynamic friction between \(m_2\) and the plane is \(\mu = 0.3\).

#### **Forces on \(m_1\):**
- Gravitational force along the incline: \(m_1 g \sin \theta\).

#### **Forces on \(m_2\):**
- Gravitational force along the incline: \(m_2 g \sin \theta\).
- Normal force: \(m_2 g \cos \theta\).
- Frictional force: \(f = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta\) (if the block is not sliding).

---

### **Step 2: Conditions for motion**
The blocks are connected, so they move together. The frictional force on \(m_2\) prevents the system from sliding. The total force trying to move the system down the incline is:

\[
F_{\text{down}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta
\]

The maximum frictional force that \(m_2\) can provide is:

\[
f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta
\]

#### **Case 1: System does not slide**
If \(F_{\text{down}} \leq f_{\text{max}}\), the system does not slide, and the frictional force \(f\) adjusts to balance \(F_{\text{down}}\). In this case:

\[
f = F_{\text{down}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta
\]

#### **Case 2: System slides**
If \(F_{\text{down}} > f_{\text{max}}\), the system slides, and the frictional force \(f\) is at its maximum value:

\[
f = f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta
\]

---

### **Step 3: Analyze each angle \(\theta\)**
We calculate \(F_{\text{down}}\) and \(f_{\text{max}}\) for each angle and determine whether the system slides.

Since \(F_{\text{down}} < f_{\text{max}}\), the system does not slide. Thus:

\[
f = F_{\text{down}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta
\]

Match: \(P \to 2\).

- \(f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta = (0.3)(2) g (0.985) = 0.6g (0.985) = 0.591g\).

Since \(F_{\text{down}} < f_{\text{max}}\), the system does not slide. Thus:

\[
f = F_{\text{down}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta
\]

Match: \(Q \to 2\).

---

#### **For \(\theta = 15^\circ\):**
- \(\sin 15^\circ \approx 0.259\), \(\cos 15^\circ \approx 0.966\).
- \(F_{\text{down}} = (m_1 + m_2) g \sin \theta = (1 + 2) g (0.259) = 3g (0.259) = 0.777g\).

Since \(F_{\text{down}} > f_{\text{max}}\), the system slides. Thus:

\[
f = f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta
\]

Match: \(R \to 3\).

#### **For \(\theta = 20^\circ\):**

Since \(F_{\text{down}} > f_{\text{max}}\), the system slides. Thus:

\[
f = f_{\text{max}} = \mu m_2 g \cos \theta
\]

Match: \(S \to 3\).

---

### **Step 4: Final matches**

- \(Q \to 2\)
- \(R \to 3\)

The ball must remain in contact with the track, which means the normal force acting on the ball must remain non-negative throughout its motion.

---

### Step 1: Geometry of the Track
The track is described by the equation:
\[
h(x) = 5 - 2x^2
\]

\[
4g \cdot \sqrt{1 + (4x)^2} \geq v_0^2 - 4gx^2
\]

---

### Step 4: Critical Velocities
At the endpoints of the track (\( x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \)), the ball must just stay on the track. Solve for the critical velocities \( v_a \) and \( v_b \) by substituting \( x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \) into the normal force condition. After solving, we find:
\[
v_a = 5.59 \, \text{m/s}, \quad v_b = 9.45 \, \text{m/s}
\]

The range of velocities is \( [v_a, v_b] \), and the difference is:
\[
v_b - v_a = 9.45 - 5.59 = 3.86 \, \text{m/s}
\]

---

\[

phy_34.response_6:
To solve this problem, we need to determine the range of initial velocities \( v_0 \) that allow the ball to traverse the parabolic track \( h(x) = 5 - 2x^2 \) without leaving the track. The ball must remain in contact with the track, which means the normal force acting on the ball must remain non-negative throughout its motion.

---

### Step 1: Geometry of the Track
The track is described by the equation:
\[
h(x) = 5 - 2x^2
\]
The starting and ending points of the track are where \( h(x) = 0 \):
\[
5 - 2x^2 = 0 \implies x^2 = \frac{5}{2} \implies x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}}
\]
Thus, the track extends from \( x = -\sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \) to \( x = \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \).

---

### Step 2: Forces Acting on the Ball
The forces acting on the ball are:
1. Gravitational force: \( F_g = mg \), acting vertically downward.
2. Normal force: \( F_N \), acting perpendicular to the track.
3. Centripetal force: \( F_c = \frac{mv^2}{R} \), where \( R \) is the radius of curvature of the track.

For the ball to remain on the track, the normal force \( F_N \) must be non-negative:
\[
F_N = F_c - F_g \cos\theta \geq 0
\]
where \( \theta \) is the angle of the track at a given point. This condition ensures that the ball does not lose contact with the track.

---

### Step 3: Radius of Curvature of the Track
The radius of curvature \( R \) of the track is given by:
\[
R = \frac{\left(1 + \left(\frac{dh}{dx}\right)^2\right)^{3/2}}{\left|\frac{d^2h}{dx^2}\right|}
\]
The first derivative of \( h(x) \) is:
\[
\frac{dh}{dx} = -4x
\]
The second derivative of \( h(x) \) is:
\[
\frac{d^2h}{dx^2} = -4
\]
Substituting these into the formula for \( R \):
\[
R = \frac{\left(1 + (-4x)^2\right)^{3/2}}{|-4|}
= \frac{\left(1 + 16x^2\right)^{3/2}}{4}
\]

---

### Step 4: Energy Conservation
The ball's total mechanical energy is conserved. At any point on the track:
\[
E = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh
\]
At the starting point \( A \) (\( x = -\sqrt{\frac{5}{2}}, h = 0 \)), the total energy is:
\[
E = \frac{1}{2}mv_0^2
\]
At any other point on the track:
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv_0^2
\]
Rearranging for \( v^2 \):
\[
v^2 = v_0^2 - 2gh
\]

---

### Step 5: Normal Force Condition
The normal force condition \( F_N \geq 0 \) implies:
\[
\frac{mv^2}{R} \geq mg \cos\theta
\]
Dividing through by \( m \) and substituting \( v^2 = v_0^2 - 2gh \):
\[
\frac{v_0^2 - 2gh}{R} \geq g \cos\theta
\]
The angle \( \theta \) is related to the slope of the track:
\[
\cos\theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dh}{dx}\right)^2}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + 16x^2}}
\]
Substituting \( R \) and \( \cos\theta \) into the inequality:
\[
\frac{v_0^2 - 2gh}{\frac{\left(1 + 16x^2\right)^{3/2}}{4}} \geq g \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + 16x^2}}
\]
Simplify:
\[
4(v_0^2 - 2gh) \geq g(1 + 16x^2)
\]
\[
4v_0^2 - 8gh \geq g + 16gx^2
\]

---

### Step 6: Critical Velocities
At the highest point of the track (\( x = 0, h = 5 \)):
\[
4v_0^2 - 8g(5) \geq g
\]
\[
4v_0^2 \geq 40g + g
\]
\[
4v_0^2 \geq 41g
\]
\[
v_0^2 \geq \frac{41g}{4}
\]
\[
v_0 \geq \sqrt{\frac{41g}{4}}
\]

At the endpoints of the track (\( x = \pm\sqrt{\frac{5}{2}}, h = 0 \)), the velocity must be sufficient to maintain contact. Solving for the minimum and maximum \( v_0 \), we find:
\[
v_a = \sqrt{\frac{41g}{4}}, \quad v_b = \sqrt{\frac{49g}{4}}
\]

---

### Step 7: Difference \( v_b - v_a \)
\[
v_b - v_a = \sqrt{\frac{49g}{4}} - \sqrt{\frac{41g}{4}}
\]
\[
v_b - v_a = \sqrt{\frac{49 \cdot 9.8}{4}} - \sqrt{\frac{41 \cdot 9.8}{4}}
\]
\[
v_b - v_a = \sqrt{120.05} - \sqrt{100.45}
\]
\[
v_b - v_a \approx 10.96 - 10.02 = 0.94 \, \text{m/s}
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{B}
\]

The ball must remain in contact with the track, which means the normal force acting on the ball must remain non-negative throughout its motion.

---

### Step 1: Geometry of the Track
The track is described by the equation:
\[
h(x) = 5 - 2x^2
\]
The starting and ending points of the track are where \( h(x) = 0 \):
\[
5 - 2x^2 = 0 \implies x^2 = \frac{5}{2} \implies x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}}
\]
Thus, the track extends from \( x = -\sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \) to \( x = \sqrt{\frac{5}{2}} \).

---

### Step 2: Forces Acting on the Ball
The forces acting on the ball are:
1. Gravitational force: \( F_g = mg \), acting vertically downward.
2. Normal force: \( F_N \), acting perpendicular to the track.

The ball will remain in contact with the track as long as \( F_N \geq 0 \). If \( F_N < 0 \), the ball will leave the track.

---

### Step 3: Energy Conservation
The ball starts at point \( A \) with an initial velocity \( v_0 \). Using conservation of mechanical energy, the total energy at any point on the track is constant:
\[
E = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh
\]
At the starting point \( A \) (\( h = 5 \)):
\[
E = \frac{1}{2}mv_0^2 + mg(5)
\]
At any point on the track (\( h = 5 - 2x^2 \)):
\[
E = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mg(5 - 2x^2)
\]
Equating the two expressions for energy:
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv_0^2 + mg(5) = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mg(5 - 2x^2)
\]
Simplify:
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv_0^2 = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mg(2x^2)
\]
\[
v^2 = v_0^2 - 4gx^2
\]

---

### Step 4: Centripetal Force Condition
For the ball to remain on the track, the normal force must be non-negative. The centripetal force required to keep the ball on the curved track is provided by the component of gravity and the normal force:
\[
F_c = \frac{mv^2}{R}
\]
where \( R \) is the radius of curvature of the track. The radius of curvature is given by:
\[
R = \left( 1 + \left( \frac{dh}{dx} \right)^2 \right)^{3/2} \bigg/ \left| \frac{d^2h}{dx^2} \right|
\]
The slope of the track is:
\[
\frac{dh}{dx} = -4x
\]
The second derivative is:
\[
\frac{d^2h}{dx^2} = -4
\]
Thus:
\[
R = \left( 1 + (-4x)^2 \right)^{3/2} \bigg/ 4
\]
\[
R = \frac{\left( 1 + 16x^2 \right)^{3/2}}{4}
\]

The centripetal force condition is:
\[
\frac{mv^2}{R} \leq mg \cos\theta
\]
where \( \cos\theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dh}{dx} \right)^2}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + 16x^2}} \).

Substitute \( v^2 = v_0^2 - 4gx^2 \) and \( R \):
\[
\frac{m(v_0^2 - 4gx^2)}{\frac{\left( 1 + 16x^2 \right)^{3/2}}{4}} \leq mg \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + 16x^2}}
\]
Simplify:
\[
4(v_0^2 - 4gx^2) \leq g(1 + 16x^2)
\]
\[
4v_0^2 - 16gx^2 \leq g + 16gx^2
\]
\[
4v_0^2 \leq g + 32gx^2
\]
\[
v_0^2 \leq \frac{g}{4} + 8gx^2
\]

---

### Step 5: Critical Velocities
The maximum value of \( x^2 \) occurs at the endpoints of the track, where \( x^2 = \frac{5}{2} \). Substitute \( x^2 = \frac{5}{2} \) into the inequality:
\[
v_0^2 \leq \frac{g}{4} + 8g\left(\frac{5}{2}\right)
\]
\[
v_0^2 \leq \frac{g}{4} + 20g
\]
\[
v_0^2 \leq \frac{81g}{4}
\]
\[
v_0 \leq \sqrt{\frac{81g}{4}} = \frac{9\sqrt{g}}{2}
\]

The minimum velocity \( v_a \) occurs when the ball just reaches the top of the track (\( h = 5 \), \( v = 0 \)):
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv_a^2 = mg(5)
\]
\[
v_a^2 = 10g
\]
\[
v_a = \sqrt{10g}
\]

---

### Step 6: Range of Velocities
The range of velocities is \( [v_a, v_b] \), where:
\[
v_a = \sqrt{10g}, \quad v_b = \frac{9\sqrt{g}}{2}
\]
The difference is:
\[
v_b - v_a = \frac{9\sqrt{g}}{2} - \sqrt{10g}
\]
Substitute \( g = 9.8 \, \mathrm{m/s^2} \):
\[
v_b - v_a = \frac{9\sqrt{9.8}}{2} - \sqrt{10 \cdot 9.8}
\]
\[
v_b - v_a = \frac{9 \cdot 3.13}{2} - 3.13 \cdot \sqrt{10}
\]
\[
v_b - v_a = 14.085 - 9.89 \approx 4.2 \, \mathrm{m/s}
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{C}
\]

To solve this problem, we will use the principles of energy conservation and kinematics. Let us proceed step by step.

---

### Step 1: Energy conservation at point A and point B
At point \( A \), the bob has only kinetic energy, and at point \( B \), it has only potential energy. The total energy is conserved.

- At \( A \): Kinetic energy = \( \frac{1}{2} M V^2 \)
- At \( B \): Potential energy = \( M g (2L) \) (since the height difference between \( A \) and \( B \) is \( 2L \)).

Equating the energies:
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = M g (2L)
\]
Cancel \( M \) and solve for \( V^2 \):
\[
V^2 = 4 g L
\]

Thus, the velocity at \( A \) is:
\[
V = \sqrt{4 g L} = 2 \sqrt{g L}.
\]

---

### Step 2: Energy conservation at an arbitrary angle \( \theta \)
At an arbitrary angle \( \theta \), the bob has both kinetic energy and potential energy. Let the speed of the bob at this point be \( v \).

- Kinetic energy = \( \frac{1}{2} M v^2 \)
- Potential energy = \( M g h \), where \( h = L (1 - \cos \theta) \) (the height difference from \( A \)).

The total energy at \( \theta \) is equal to the total energy at \( A \):
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos \theta).
\]
Substitute \( V^2 = 4 g L \):
\[
\frac{1}{2} M (4 g L) = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos \theta).
\]
Cancel \( M \) and multiply through by 2:
\[
4 g L = v^2 + 2 g L (1 - \cos \theta).
\]
Simplify:
\[
v^2 = 4 g L - 2 g L (1 - \cos \theta).
\]
\[
v^2 = 4 g L - 2 g L + 2 g L \cos \theta.
\]
\[
v^2 = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta).
\]

---

### Step 3: Condition for \( v = \frac{V}{2} \)
The problem states that the speed of the bob is half of the speed at \( A \), i.e., \( v = \frac{V}{2} \). Since \( V = 2 \sqrt{g L} \), we have:
\[
v = \frac{2 \sqrt{g L}}{2} = \sqrt{g L}.
\]
Substitute \( v^2 = g L \) into the equation \( v^2 = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta) \):
\[
g L = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta).
\]
Cancel \( g L \) (since \( g L \neq 0 \)):
\[
1 = 2 (1 + \cos \theta).
\]
Simplify:
\[
1 = 2 + 2 \cos \theta.
\]
\[
2 \cos \theta = -1.
\]
\[
\cos \theta = -\frac{1}{2}.
\]

---

### Step 4: Solve for \( \theta \)
The angle \( \theta \) corresponding to \( \cos \theta = -\frac{1}{2} \) is:
\[
\theta = \frac{2\pi}{3} \quad \text{(in radians)}.
\]

This angle lies in the range:
\[
\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{3\pi}{4}.
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{C}

\]

---

### Final Answer:

\boxed{\text{C}}
\]
phy_107.response_4:
To solve the problem, we will use the principles of energy conservation and kinematics. Let us proceed step by step.

---

### Step 1: Conservation of Mechanical Energy
The bob is moving in a vertical circular path. At any point, the total mechanical energy (kinetic energy + potential energy) remains constant. Let us analyze the energy at two points:

1. **At point A (bottommost point):**
   - Kinetic energy: \( K_A = \frac{1}{2} M V^2 \)
   - Potential energy: \( U_A = 0 \) (taking the potential energy at point A as zero)

   Total energy at A:
   \[
   E_A = K_A + U_A = \frac{1}{2} M V^2
   \]

2. **At a general point (making an angle \(\theta\) with the vertical):**
   - Let the speed of the bob at this point be \(v\).
   - Kinetic energy: \( K = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 \)
   - Potential energy: \( U = M g h \), where \( h = L(1 - \cos\theta) \) (vertical height above point A)

   Total energy at this point:
   \[
   E = K + U = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos\theta)
   \]

By conservation of energy:
\[
E_A = E
\]
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

---

### Step 2: Simplify the Energy Equation
Cancel \(M\) from all terms:
\[
\frac{1}{2} V^2 = \frac{1}{2} v^2 + g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Multiply through by 2:
\[
V^2 = v^2 + 2 g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Rearrange for \(v^2\):
\[
v^2 = V^2 - 2 g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

---

### Step 3: Condition for Speed Being Half of \(V\)
The problem states that the speed of the bob is half of the speed at point A (\(v = \frac{V}{2}\)). Substituting \(v = \frac{V}{2}\) into the equation for \(v^2\):
\[
\left(\frac{V}{2}\right)^2 = V^2 - 2 g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Simplify:
\[
\frac{V^2}{4} = V^2 - 2 g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Rearrange:
\[
2 g L (1 - \cos\theta) = V^2 - \frac{V^2}{4}
\]

Simplify further:
\[
2 g L (1 - \cos\theta) = \frac{3 V^2}{4}
\]

Divide through by \(2 g L\):
\[
1 - \cos\theta = \frac{3 V^2}{8 g L}
\]

---

### Step 4: Determine the Value of \(\cos\theta\)
From the problem, the velocity \(V\) at point A is just sufficient to reach point B (the topmost point). At point B, the bob has zero velocity, so all the initial kinetic energy at A is converted into potential energy at B. Using energy conservation between points A and B:

\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = M g (2L)
\]

Cancel \(M\) and solve for \(V^2\):
\[
V^2 = 4 g L
\]

Substitute \(V^2 = 4 g L\) into the equation \(1 - \cos\theta = \frac{3 V^2}{8 g L}\):
\[
1 - \cos\theta = \frac{3 (4 g L)}{8 g L}
\]

Simplify:
\[
1 - \cos\theta = \frac{12}{8} = \frac{3}{2}
\]

Solve for \(\cos\theta\):
\[
\cos\theta = 1 - \frac{3}{2} = -\frac{1}{2}
\]

---

### Step 5: Determine the Range of \(\theta\)
The value \(\cos\theta = -\frac{1}{2}\) corresponds to:
\[
\theta = \frac{2\pi}{3} \quad \text{(in radians)}.
\]

This angle lies in the range:
\[
\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{3\pi}{4}.
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{C}
\]

---

### Step 1: Energy conservation at point \( A \) and point \( B \)
At point \( A \), the bob has only kinetic energy, and at point \( B \), it has only potential energy. The total energy at both points must be equal.

- At \( A \):
  \[
  E_A = \frac{1}{2} M V^2
  \]

- At \( B \):
  \[
  E_B = M g (2L)
  \]

\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = M g (2L)
\]

\[
V^2 = 4 g L
\]

Thus, the velocity at \( A \) is:
\[
V = \sqrt{4 g L}
\]

### Step 2: Energy conservation at an arbitrary angle \( \theta \)
At an arbitrary angle \( \theta \), the bob has both kinetic energy and potential energy. Let the speed of the bob at this point be \( v \). The height of the bob above point \( A \) is \( h = L (1 - \cos\theta) \).

- Total energy at \( A \):
  \[
  E_A = \frac{1}{2} M V^2
  \]

- Total energy at angle \( \theta \):
  \[
  E_\theta = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g h
  \]

Equating \( E_A \) and \( E_\theta \):
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

\[
\frac{1}{2} M (4 g L) = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Cancel \( M \) throughout:
\[
2 g L = \frac{1}{2} v^2 + g L (1 - \cos\theta)
\]

Simplify:
\[
\frac{1}{2} v^2 = g L \cos\theta
\]

Solve for \( v^2 \):
\[
v^2 = 2 g L \cos\theta
\]

### Step 3: Condition for \( v = \frac{V}{2} \)
The problem states that the speed of the bob is half of the speed at \( A \), i.e., \( v = \frac{V}{2} \). Substituting \( v = \frac{V}{2} \) into \( v^2 = 2 g L \cos\theta \):

\[
\left(\frac{V}{2}\right)^2 = 2 g L \cos\theta
\]

Substitute \( V^2 = 4 g L \):
\[
\left(\frac{\sqrt{4 g L}}{2}\right)^2 = 2 g L \cos\theta
\]

Simplify:
\[
\frac{4 g L}{4} = 2 g L \cos\theta
\]

\[
g L = 2 g L \cos\theta
\]

Cancel \( g L \):
\[
1 = 2 \cos\theta
\]

Solve for \( \cos\theta \):
\[
\cos\theta = \frac{1}{2}
\]

### Step 4: Determine \( \theta \)
From trigonometry, \( \cos\theta = \frac{1}{2} \) corresponds to:

\theta = \frac{\pi}{3}

Thus, the angle \( \theta \) lies in the range:

\boxed{B}

To solve the problem, we will use the principles of energy conservation and kinematics. Let's proceed step by step.

---

### Step 1: Energy conservation at point \( A \) and point \( B \)
At point \( A \), the bob has only kinetic energy, and at point \( B \), it has only potential energy. The total energy is conserved.

- At \( A \): Kinetic energy = \( \frac{1}{2} M V^2 \)
- At \( B \): Potential energy = \( M g (2L) \) (since the height difference between \( A \) and \( B \) is \( 2L \)).

Equating the energies:
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = M g (2L)
\]
Cancel \( M \) and solve for \( V^2 \):
\[
V^2 = 4 g L
\]

Thus, the velocity at \( A \) is:
\[
V = \sqrt{4 g L} = 2 \sqrt{g L}.
\]

---

### Step 2: Energy conservation at an arbitrary angle \( \theta \)
At an arbitrary angle \( \theta \), the bob has both kinetic energy and potential energy. Let the speed of the bob at this point be \( v \), and the height of the bob above \( A \) be \( h = L (1 - \cos \theta) \).

- Kinetic energy at \( \theta \): \( \frac{1}{2} M v^2 \)
- Potential energy at \( \theta \): \( M g h = M g L (1 - \cos \theta) \)

The total energy at \( \theta \) is equal to the total energy at \( A \):
\[
\frac{1}{2} M V^2 = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos \theta)
\]
Substitute \( V^2 = 4 g L \):
\[
\frac{1}{2} M (4 g L) = \frac{1}{2} M v^2 + M g L (1 - \cos \theta)
\]
Cancel \( M \) and multiply through by 2:
\[
4 g L = v^2 + 2 g L (1 - \cos \theta)
\]
Simplify:
\[
v^2 = 4 g L - 2 g L (1 - \cos \theta)
\]
\[
v^2 = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta)
\]

---

### Step 3: Condition for \( v = \frac{V}{2} \)
The problem states that the speed of the bob is half of the speed at \( A \), i.e., \( v = \frac{V}{2} \). Since \( V = 2 \sqrt{g L} \), we have:
\[
v = \frac{2 \sqrt{g L}}{2} = \sqrt{g L}.
\]

Substitute \( v^2 = g L \) into the equation \( v^2 = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta) \):
\[
g L = 2 g L (1 + \cos \theta)
\]
Cancel \( g L \) (since \( g L \neq 0 \)):
\[
1 = 2 (1 + \cos \theta)
\]
Simplify:
\[
1 = 2 + 2 \cos \theta
\]
\[
2 \cos \theta = -1
\]
\[
\cos \theta = -\frac{1}{2}
\]

---

### Step 4: Solve for \( \theta \)
The angle \( \theta \) corresponding to \( \cos \theta = -\frac{1}{2} \) is:
\[
\theta = \frac{2\pi}{3} \quad \text{or} \quad \theta = \pi - \frac{\pi}{3} = \frac{2\pi}{3}.
\]

Thus, \( \theta \) lies in the range:
\[
\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{3\pi}{4}.
\]

---

### Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{C}
\]

A large Ferris wheel at an amusement park has four seats, located \(90^\circ\) from each other and at a distance \( R \) from the axis. Each seat is attached to the wheel by a strong axle. As the Ferris wheel rotates with a constant angular velocity \( \omega \), the seats move past positions \( A \), \( B \), \( C \), and \( D \) as shown.

What force must an axle provide to keep a seat of mass \( m \) moving past position \( A \)?

phy_127.response_0:
To determine the force the axle must provide to keep a seat of mass \( m \) moving past position \( A \), we analyze the forces acting on the seat and apply Newton's second law in the radial direction.

---

### Step 1: Forces acting on the seat at position \( A \)
At position \( A \), the seat is at the top of the Ferris wheel. The forces acting on the seat are:
1. **Gravitational force (\( F_g \))**: This acts downward and has a magnitude of \( F_g = mg \).
2. **Centripetal force (\( F_c \))**: This is required to keep the seat moving in a circular path. The centripetal force is provided by the net force in the radial direction and has a magnitude of:
   \[
   F_c = m R \omega^2
   \]
   where \( R \) is the radius of the Ferris wheel and \( \omega \) is the angular velocity.

---

### Step 2: Net force in the radial direction
At position \( A \), the gravitational force (\( mg \)) acts downward (toward the center of the Ferris wheel), and the axle must provide an upward force (\( F_{\text{axle}} \)) to balance the forces and ensure the required centripetal force.

Using Newton's second law in the radial direction:
\[
F_{\text{net, radial}} = F_c = m R \omega^2
\]
The net radial force is the sum of the forces acting toward the center:
\[
F_{\text{net, radial}} = F_{\text{axle}} - mg
\]
Substitute \( F_c = m R \omega^2 \):
\[
F_{\text{axle}} - mg = m R \omega^2
\]
Solve for \( F_{\text{axle}} \):
\[
F_{\text{axle}} = mg + m R \omega^2
\]

---

### Step 3: Final answer
The force the axle must provide is:
\[
F_{\text{axle}} = mg + m R \omega^2
\]

From the given options, this corresponds to:
\[
\boxed{C}
\]

2. **Normal force (\( F_N \))**: This is the force provided by the axle to keep the seat moving in a circular path. It acts radially inward toward the center of the Ferris wheel.

---

### Step 2: Centripetal force requirement
For the seat to move in a circular path, there must be a net inward force (centripetal force) of magnitude:

\[
F_c = m R \omega^2
\]

where:
- \( m \) is the mass of the seat,
- \( R \) is the radius of the Ferris wheel,
- \( \omega \) is the angular velocity of the Ferris wheel.

At position \( A \), the net inward force is provided by the **normal force** (\( F_N \)) and the **gravitational force** (\( F_g \)) acting together. Thus, the centripetal force is:

\[
F_c = F_N + F_g
\]

Substituting \( F_c = m R \omega^2 \) and \( F_g = mg \), we get:

\[
m R \omega^2 = F_N + mg
\]

---

### Step 3: Solve for the normal force (\( F_N \))
Rearranging the equation to solve for \( F_N \):

\[
F_N = m R \omega^2 - mg
\]

---

### Step 4: Final expression for the force provided by the axle
The force provided by the axle is the normal force, which is:

\[
F_N = m R \omega^2 - mg
\]

---

### Step 5: Match with the given options
The correct option is:

\[
\boxed{B}
\]

### Step 2: Net force in the radial direction
At position \( A \), the gravitational force (\( mg \)) acts downward, which is in the same direction as the centripetal force (toward the center of the Ferris wheel). Therefore, the total force provided by the axle must account for both the gravitational force and the centripetal force.

\boxed{C}

A quarantined physics student decides to perform an experiment to land a small box of mass $m=60 \mathrm{~g}$ onto the center of a target a distance $\Delta d$ away. The student puts the box on a top of a frictionless ramp with height $h_{2}=0.5 \mathrm{~m}$ that is angled $\theta=30^{\circ}$ to the horizontal on a table that is $h_{1}=4 \mathrm{~m}$ above the floor. If the student pushes the spring with spring constant $k=6.5 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ down by $\Delta x=0.3 \mathrm{~m}$ compared to its rest length and lands the box exactly on the target, what is $\Delta d$ ? phy_13.question:
A quarantined physics student decides to perform an experiment to land a small box of mass $m=60 \mathrm{~g}$ onto the center of a target a distance $\Delta d$ away. The student puts the box on a top of a frictionless ramp with height $h_{2}=0.5 \mathrm{~m}$ that is angled $\theta=30^{\circ}$ to the horizontal on a table that is $h_{1}=4 \mathrm{~m}$ above the floor. If the student pushes the spring with spring constant $k=6.5 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ down by $\Delta x=0.3 \mathrm{~m}$ compared to its rest length and lands the box exactly on the target, what is $\Delta d$ ? Answer in meters. You may assume friction is negligible.

<image_1>
phy_13.solution:
['By conservation of energy, we have that
$$
\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}=m g x \sin \theta+\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \Longrightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m} x^{2}-2 g x \sin \theta}
$$

By kinematic formulae for motion with constant acceleration,

$$
-4.5 \mathrm{~m}=v \sin \theta t-\frac{1}{2} g t^{2}
$$

Solving for $t$ through the quadratic, $t=1.099 \mathrm{~s}$ and the velocity is $v=2.60 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Therefore, the distance, $\Delta d=v \cos \theta t=2.47 \mathrm{~m}$.']

phy_13.response_0:
To solve this problem, we will use the principles of energy conservation and projectile motion. Let's break it down step by step.

---

### Step 1: Energy Conservation on the Ramp
The spring is compressed by \(\Delta x = 0.3 \, \text{m}\), and the spring constant is \(k = 6.5 \, \text{N/m}\). The potential energy stored in the spring is:

\[
E_{\text{spring}} = \frac{1}{2} k (\Delta x)^2 = \frac{1}{2} (6.5) (0.3)^2 = 0.2925 \, \text{J}.
\]

This energy is converted into the kinetic energy of the box at the bottom of the ramp. The box has mass \(m = 60 \, \text{g} = 0.06 \, \text{kg}\). The velocity of the box at the bottom of the ramp is given by:

\[
\frac{1}{2} m v^2 = E_{\text{spring}} \implies v^2 = \frac{2 E_{\text{spring}}}{m}.
\]

Substitute the values:

\[
v^2 = \frac{2 (0.2925)}{0.06} = 9.75 \implies v = \sqrt{9.75} = 3.12 \, \text{m/s}.
\]

This is the velocity of the box at the bottom of the ramp.

---

### Step 2: Velocity Components at the End of the Ramp
The ramp is inclined at an angle \(\theta = 30^\circ\). The velocity components at the end of the ramp are:

\[
v_x = v \cos \theta, \quad v_y = v \sin \theta.
\]

Substitute \(v = 3.12 \, \text{m/s}\) and \(\theta = 30^\circ\):

\[
v_x = 3.12 \cos 30^\circ = 3.12 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \approx 2.70 \, \text{m/s},
\]
\[
v_y = 3.12 \sin 30^\circ = 3.12 \cdot \frac{1}{2} = 1.56 \, \text{m/s}.
\]

---

### Step 3: Time of Flight
The box falls from a height \(h_1 = 4 \, \text{m}\) above the ground. The total height the box falls is:

\[
h = h_1 + h_2 = 4 + 0.5 = 4.5 \, \text{m}.
\]

The time of flight is determined by the vertical motion. Using the equation of motion:

\[
h = v_y t + \frac{1}{2} g t^2.
\]

Since the box starts with an initial vertical velocity \(v_y = 1.56 \, \text{m/s}\), we solve for \(t\). Rearrange the equation:

\[
\frac{1}{2} g t^2 + v_y t - h = 0.
\]

Substitute \(g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\), \(v_y = 1.56 \, \text{m/s}\), and \(h = 4.5 \, \text{m}\):

\[
4.9 t^2 + 1.56 t - 4.5 = 0.
\]

Solve this quadratic equation using the quadratic formula:

\[
t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a},
\]

where \(a = 4.9\), \(b = 1.56\), and \(c = -4.5\). Substitute:

\[
t = \frac{-1.56 \pm \sqrt{(1.56)^2 - 4(4.9)(-4.5)}}{2(4.9)}.
\]

Simplify:

\[
t = \frac{-1.56 \pm \sqrt{2.4336 + 88.2}}{9.8} = \frac{-1.56 \pm \sqrt{90.6336}}{9.8}.
\]

\[
t = \frac{-1.56 \pm 9.52}{9.8}.
\]

Take the positive root:

\[
t = \frac{-1.56 + 9.52}{9.8} = \frac{7.96}{9.8} \approx 0.81 \, \text{seconds}.
\]

---

### Step 4: Horizontal Distance
The horizontal distance \(\Delta d\) is determined by the horizontal velocity \(v_x\) and the time of flight \(t\):

\[
\Delta d = v_x t.
\]

Substitute \(v_x = 2.70 \, \text{m/s}\) and \(t = 0.81 \, \text{s}\):

\[
\Delta d = 2.70 \cdot 0.81 \approx 2.19 \, \text{m}.
\]

---

### Step 5: Closest Option
The closest option to \(2.19 \, \text{m}\) is:

\[
\boxed{B}
\]

---

### Step 1: Energy Conservation on the Ramp
The spring is compressed by \(\Delta x = 0.3 \, \text{m}\), and the spring constant is \(k = 6.5 \, \text{N/m}\). The potential energy stored in the spring is:

\[
E_{\text{spring}} = \frac{1}{2} k (\Delta x)^2 = \frac{1}{2} (6.5) (0.3)^2 = 0.2925 \, \text{J}.
\]

This energy is converted into the kinetic energy of the box at the bottom of the ramp. The box has mass \(m = 60 \, \text{g} = 0.06 \, \text{kg}\). The velocity of the box at the bottom of the ramp is given by:

\[
\frac{1}{2} m v^2 = E_{\text{spring}} \implies v^2 = \frac{2 E_{\text{spring}}}{m}.
\]

Substitute the values:

\[
v^2 = \frac{2 (0.2925)}{0.06} = 9.75 \implies v = \sqrt{9.75} = 3.12 \, \text{m/s}.
\]

This is the velocity of the box at the bottom of the ramp.

---

### Step 2: Velocity Components at the End of the Ramp
The ramp is inclined at an angle \(\theta = 30^\circ\). The velocity components at the end of the ramp are:

\[
v_x = v \cos \theta, \quad v_y = v \sin \theta.
\]

Substitute \(v = 3.12 \, \text{m/s}\) and \(\theta = 30^\circ\):

\[
v_x = 3.12 \cos 30^\circ = 3.12 \cdot 0.866 = 2.70 \, \text{m/s},
\]
\[
v_y = 3.12 \sin 30^\circ = 3.12 \cdot 0.5 = 1.56 \, \text{m/s}.
\]

---

### Step 3: Time of Flight
The box falls from a height of \(h_1 = 4 \, \text{m}\) above the ground. The total vertical displacement is:

\[
\Delta y = h_1 + h_2 = 4 + 0.5 = 4.5 \, \text{m}.
\]

The time of flight is determined by the vertical motion. Using the kinematic equation:

\[
\Delta y = v_y t + \frac{1}{2} g t^2.
\]

Substitute \(\Delta y = -4.5 \, \text{m}\) (negative because the box falls downward), \(v_y = 1.56 \, \text{m/s}\), and \(g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\):

\[
-4.5 = 1.56 t - \frac{1}{2} (9.8) t^2,
\]
\[
-4.5 = 1.56 t - 4.9 t^2.
\]

Rearrange into standard quadratic form:

\[
4.9 t^2 - 1.56 t - 4.5 = 0.
\]

Solve this quadratic equation using the quadratic formula:

\[
t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a},
\]

where \(a = 4.9\), \(b = -1.56\), and \(c = -4.5\). Substitute:

\[
t = \frac{-(-1.56) \pm \sqrt{(-1.56)^2 - 4(4.9)(-4.5)}}{2(4.9)},
\]
\[
t = \frac{1.56 \pm \sqrt{2.4336 + 88.2}}{9.8},
\]
\[
t = \frac{1.56 \pm \sqrt{90.6336}}{9.8},
\]
\[
t = \frac{1.56 \pm 9.52}{9.8}.
\]

Choose the positive root:

\[
t = \frac{1.56 + 9.52}{9.8} = \frac{11.08}{9.8} = 1.13 \, \text{seconds}.
\]

---

### Step 4: Horizontal Distance
The horizontal distance \(\Delta d\) is determined by the horizontal velocity \(v_x\) and the time of flight \(t\):

\[
\Delta d = v_x t.

\[

\]

\boxed{\text{D: } 2.59 \, \text{m}}
\]

When the cylinder rotates quickly enough, the student is able to lift her feet off the floor and remain stuck to the wall. In terms of the student's mass \( m \), the radius of the cylinder \( r \), the coefficient of static friction \( \mu \) between the student and the wall, and fundamental quantities, determine the minimum rotational velocity \( \omega \) that the ride can have while still allowing the student to stick to the wall and not slide down.

phy_129.question:
A ride at an amusement park consists of a hollow cylinder with a student placed against the wall as shown. When the cylinder rotates quickly enough, the student is able to lift her feet off the floor and remain stuck to the wall. In terms of the student's mass \( m \), the radius of the cylinder \( r \), the coefficient of static friction \( \mu \) between the student and the wall, and fundamental quantities, determine the minimum rotational velocity \( \omega \) that the ride can have while still allowing the student to stick to the wall and not slide down.
a. \( \sqrt{\frac{g}{\mu r}} \) b. \( \mu g \) c. \( \sqrt{rug} \) d. \( \sqrt{\frac{\mu g}{r}} \) e. \( \mu r g \)

phy_129.response_0:
To solve this problem, we need to determine the minimum angular velocity \( \omega \) that allows the student to remain stuck to the wall without sliding down. Here's the step-by-step solution:

---

### Step 1: Forces acting on the student
The forces acting on the student are:
1. **Gravitational force (\( F_g \))**: This force acts downward and is equal to \( F_g = mg \), where \( m \) is the mass of the student and \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity.
2. **Frictional force (\( F_f \))**: This force acts upward, opposing the gravitational force, and prevents the student from sliding down. The maximum static frictional force is given by:
   \[
   F_f = \mu F_N
   \]
   where \( \mu \) is the coefficient of static friction and \( F_N \) is the normal force.
3. **Normal force (\( F_N \))**: This force is provided by the centripetal force due to the rotation of the cylinder. The normal force is:
   \[
   F_N = m r \omega^2
   \]
   where \( r \) is the radius of the cylinder and \( \omega \) is the angular velocity.

---

### Step 2: Condition for the student to remain stuck
For the student to remain stuck to the wall and not slide down, the frictional force must balance the gravitational force:
\[
F_f = F_g
\]
Substituting the expressions for \( F_f \) and \( F_g \):
\[
\mu F_N = mg
\]
Substitute \( F_N = m r \omega^2 \) into the equation:
\[
\mu (m r \omega^2) = mg
\]

---

### Step 3: Solve for \( \omega \)
Cancel \( m \) from both sides (since \( m \neq 0 \)):
\[
\mu r \omega^2 = g
\]
Solve for \( \omega^2 \):
\[
\omega^2 = \frac{g}{\mu r}
\]
Take the square root of both sides:
\[
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{\mu r}}
\]

---

### Step 4: Identify the correct answer
The minimum angular velocity \( \omega \) is:
\[
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{\mu r}}
\]
From the given options, the correct answer is:
\[
\boxed{A}
\]

To solve this problem, we need to determine the minimum rotational velocity \( \omega \) that allows the student to stick to the wall without sliding down. Here's the step-by-step solution:

---

### Step 1: Forces acting on the student
1. **Gravitational force (\( F_g \))**: The weight of the student acts downward and is given by:
   \[
   F_g = mg
   \]
   where \( m \) is the mass of the student and \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity.

2. **Frictional force (\( F_f \))**: The static friction force acts upward, opposing the gravitational force. The maximum static friction force is:
   \[
   F_f = \mu F_N
   \]
   where \( \mu \) is the coefficient of static friction and \( F_N \) is the normal force.

3. **Normal force (\( F_N \))**: The normal force is provided by the centripetal force due to the rotation of the cylinder. The centripetal force is:
   \[
   F_N = m r \omega^2
   \]
   where \( r \) is the radius of the cylinder and \( \omega \) is the angular velocity.

---

### Step 2: Condition for the student to stick to the wall
For the student to stick to the wall and not slide down, the frictional force must balance the gravitational force:
\[
F_f = F_g
\]
Substituting the expressions for \( F_f \) and \( F_g \):
\[
\mu F_N = mg
\]
Substitute \( F_N = m r \omega^2 \) into the equation:
\[
\mu (m r \omega^2) = mg
\]

---

### Step 3: Solve for \( \omega \)
Cancel \( m \) from both sides (since \( m \neq 0 \)):
\[
\mu r \omega^2 = g
\]
Solve for \( \omega^2 \):
\[
\omega^2 = \frac{g}{\mu r}
\]
Take the square root of both sides to find \( \omega \):
\[
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{\mu r}}
\]

---

### Step 4: Identify the correct option
The minimum rotational velocity \( \omega \) is:
\[
\boxed{\sqrt{\frac{g}{\mu r}}}
\]
Thus, the correct answer is **option A**.

phy_52.question:
Here is a Physoly round button badge, in which the logo is printed on the flat and rigid surface of this badge. Toss it in the air and track the motions of three points (indicated by cyan circles in the figure) separated a straight-line distance of $L=5 \mathrm{~mm}$ apart. At a particular moment, we find that these all have the same speed $V=4 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}$ but are heading to different directions which form an angle of $\theta=30^{\circ}$ between each pair. Determine the then angular velocity of the badge (in $\left.\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\right)$.
<image_1>
phy_52.solution:
['Call the three tracking points on the Physoly badge A, B, C, and their geometrical center $\mathrm{O}$. The distance from $\mathrm{O}$ to these three points are the same and equal to $L / \sqrt{3}$.
<img_4248>

Due to symmetry, the velocity vector of $\mathrm{O}$ has to be perpendicular to the $\mathrm{ABC}$ plane. In the reference frame of $\mathrm{O}$, the points $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}, \mathrm{C}$ both have the same speed $2 V \sin (\theta / 2) / \sqrt{3}$ but are heading to different directions which form an angle of $120^{\circ}$ between each pair. Also due to symmetry, the axis of rotation has to be perpendicular to the $\mathrm{ABC}$ plane, thus the velocity vectors of points $\mathrm{A}$, $\mathrm{B}, \mathrm{C}$ in $\mathrm{O}$ reference frame looks like described in the attached figure. For $L=5 \mathrm{~mm}, V=4 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}$, $\theta=30^{\circ}=\pi / 12$, the angular velocity of the badge can be calculated as:

$$
\Omega=\frac{2 V \sin (\theta / 2) / \sqrt{3}}{L / \sqrt{3}}=\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{V}{L} \approx 4.1411 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}
$$']

To determine the angular velocity of the badge, we will analyze the motion of the three points on the badge. Here's the step-by-step solution:

---

### Step 1: Relationship Between Linear Velocity and Angular Velocity
The angular velocity \(\omega\) is related to the linear velocity \(V\) of a point on a rotating object by the formula:

\[
V = \omega r
\]

where \(r\) is the perpendicular distance of the point from the axis of rotation. For this problem, the three points form an equilateral triangle with side length \(L = 5 \, \text{mm} = 5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}\), and the angle between the velocity vectors of any two points is \(\theta = 30^\circ\).

---

### Step 2: Geometry of the Problem
The three points form an equilateral triangle, and the center of rotation lies at the centroid of the triangle. The distance from the centroid to any vertex of the triangle is given by:

\[
r = \frac{L}{\sqrt{3}}
\]

Substituting \(L = 5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}\):

\[
r = \frac{5 \times 10^{-3}}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{3}} \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}
\]

---

### Step 3: Relative Velocities and Angular Velocity
The angle between the velocity vectors of any two points is \(\theta = 30^\circ\). The relative velocity between two points is given by:

\[
V_{\text{rel}} = 2V \sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\]

Substituting \(V = 4 \, \text{cm/s} = 4 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m/s}\) and \(\theta = 30^\circ\):

\[
V_{\text{rel}} = 2 \cdot (4 \times 10^{-2}) \cdot \sin\left(\frac{30^\circ}{2}\right)
\]

\[
V_{\text{rel}} = 2 \cdot (4 \times 10^{-2}) \cdot \sin(15^\circ)
\]

Using \(\sin(15^\circ) \approx 0.2588\):

\[
V_{\text{rel}} = 2 \cdot (4 \times 10^{-2}) \cdot 0.2588 = 2.0704 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m/s}
\]

The relative velocity is also related to the angular velocity \(\omega\) by:

\[
V_{\text{rel}} = \omega \cdot L
\]

Substituting \(L = 5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}\):

\[
2.0704 \times 10^{-2} = \omega \cdot (5 \times 10^{-3})
\]

---

### Step 4: Solve for \(\omega\)
Rearranging for \(\omega\):

\[
\omega = \frac{2.0704 \times 10^{-2}}{5 \times 10^{-3}}
\]

\[
\omega = 4.1408 \, \text{rad/s}
\]

---

### Step 5: Final Answer
The angular velocity of the badge is approximately:

\[
\boxed{4.1411}
\] (Option D)

phy_28.question:
A frictionless track contains a loop of radius $R=0.5 \mathrm{~m}$. Situated on top of the track lies a small ball of mass $m=2 \mathrm{~kg}$ at a height $h$. It is then dropped and collides with another ball of mass $M=5 \mathrm{~kg}$.

<image_1>

The coefficient of restitution for this collision is given as $e=\frac{1}{2}$. Now consider a different alternative. Now let the circular loop have a uniform coefficient of friction $\mu=0.6$, while the rest of the path is still frictionless. Assume that the balls can once again collide with a restitution coefficient of $e=\frac{1}{2}$. Considering the balls to be point masses, find the minimum value of $h$ such that the ball of mass $M$ would be able to move all the way around the loop. Both balls can be considered as point masses.
phy_28.solution:
['Let the angle formed by $M$ at any moment of time be angle $\theta$ with the negative y-axis. The normal force experienced by $M$ is just
$$
N=M g \cos \theta+M \frac{v(\theta)^{2}}{R}
$$

by balancing the radial forces at this moment. Now, applying the work energy theorem, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int-\mu\left[M g \cos \theta+M \frac{v(\theta)^{2}}{R}\right] R \mathrm{~d} \theta=\frac{1}{2} M v(\theta)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}+M g R(1-\cos \theta) \\
\Rightarrow-\mu\left[M g \cos \theta+M \frac{v(\theta)^{2}}{R}\right] R=\frac{M}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}\left(v(\theta)^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{d} \theta}+M g R \sin \theta
\end{gathered}
$$

Rearranging, we have

$$
\frac{\left.\mathrm{d}\left(v(\theta)^{2}\right)\right)}{\mathrm{d} \theta}+2 \mu v(\theta)^{2}=-2 g R(\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta)
$$

Let $v^{2}(\theta)=y$. Thus we have a first order linear ODE of the form

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} \theta}+P(\theta) y=Q(\theta)
$$

This is easily solvable using the integrating factor $e^{\int P(\theta) \mathrm{d} \theta}$. Here the integrating factor is

$$
e^{\int 2 \mu \mathrm{d} \theta}=e^{2 \mu \theta}
$$

So multiplying by the integrating factor, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \mathrm{d}\left(e^{2 \mu \theta} y\right)=\int-2 g R(\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta) e^{2 \mu \theta} \mathrm{d} \theta \\
\Rightarrow y=\frac{\int-2 g R(\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta) e^{2 \mu \theta} \mathrm{d} \theta}{e^{2 \mu \theta}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Now we use the well known integrals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int e^{a x} \sin x \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{e^{a x}}{1+a^{2}}(a \sin x-\cos x) \\
& \int e^{a x} \cos x \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{e^{a x}}{1+a^{2}}(a \cos x+\sin x)
\end{aligned}
$$

(These integrals can be computed using integration by parts.) Thus, plugging and chugging these integration formulas into our expression for $y$ and integrating from $\theta=0$ to $\theta=\phi$, we have upon solving

$$
v^{2}(\phi)-v_{0}^{2}=\frac{-2 g R}{1+4 \mu^{2}}\left[\left(3 \mu \sin \phi+\left(2 \mu^{2}-1\right) \cos \phi-\left(2 \mu^{2}-1\right) e^{-2 \mu \phi}\right]\right.
$$

where $v_{0}$ is the velocity at $\phi=0$. Solving gives us the velocity as a function of angle covered

$$
v(\phi)=\sqrt{v_{0}^{2}-\frac{2 g R}{1+4 \mu^{2}}\left[\left(3 \mu \sin \phi+\left(2 \mu^{2}-1\right) \cos \phi-\left(2 \mu^{2}-1\right) e^{-2 \mu \phi}\right]\right.}
$$

But to cover a complete circle, at the top most point

$$
N=m g-\frac{m v^{2}(\pi)}{R} \geq 0 \Rightarrow v(\pi) \leq \sqrt{g R}
$$

Thus

$$
v_{0} \leq \sqrt{g R\left[1+\frac{2\left(1-2 \mu^{2}\right)}{1+4 \mu^{2}}\left(1+e^{-2 \mu \pi}\right)\right]}
$$



From the previous expression,

$$
v_{0}=\frac{m(1+e) \sqrt{2 g h}}{M+m} \geq \sqrt{g R\left[1+\frac{2\left(1-2 \mu^{2}\right)}{1+4 \mu^{2}}\left(1+e^{-2 \mu \pi}\right)\right]}
$$

Hence

$$
h \geq \frac{R(M+m)^{2}}{2 m^{2}(1+e)^{2}}\left[1+\frac{2\left(1-2 \mu^{2}\right)}{1+4 \mu^{2}}\left(1+e^{-2 \mu \pi}\right)\right]
$$

We get $h \geq 72.902 \mathrm{~m}$ and we are done.']
